round_data.response:
My reasoning:

We note that if we accept Player 1’s offer [1,0,2,0,0], our allocation would be exactly those items. That gives us:
 • item 1: 1 unit → 1×50 = 50
 • item 3: 2 units → 2×69 = 138
 • (items 2,4,5: 0 units)
for a total value of 50 + 138 = 188. This is below our outside offer value of 201. Thus, accepting is not good.

When we propose a counteroffer, we specify what we give to Player 1; we then receive whatever remains from the totals:
 • Total quantities: item1:4, item2:0, item3:4, item4:2, item5:3.
 • If our counteroffer is X = [x₁, x₂, x₃, x₄, x₅], then our allocation is [4–x₁, 0, 4–x₃, 2–x₄, 3–x₅].

Our aim is to secure a deal that gives us a present (undiscounted) value higher than our outside offer (201). One natural idea is to “push” Player 1’s offer a bit so that we get extra value. Notice that in Player 1’s offer we would get 0 units of item4 (worth 13 each to us). By “claiming” one extra unit of item4 (i.e. by keeping a unit that otherwise would have gone to Player 1), we add 13 points to our current 188, reaching 201 exactly. However, to make the division appealing (and possibly acceptable to Player 1) we want to “split” the total surplus fairly according to our own valuations.

Our full pie (by our values) is:
 item1: 4×50 = 200,
 item3: 4×69 = 276,
 item4: 2×13 = 26,
 item5: 3×15 = 45.
Total = 200 + 276 + 26 + 45 = 547.

A natural “fair” split (by our measure) is 547 being divided as 201 for one party and 346 for the other. (Notice 346 + 201 = 547.) Since our outside offer gives us 201 if no deal is reached, we must obtain at least something higher via agreement. By leaving Player 1 items that we (by our measure) value as 201 and taking the remaining 346 for ourselves we maximize our gain while giving Player 1 what (by our expectation) might be their reservation level.

To get exactly this split we must choose our counteroffer X so that our allocation is exactly:
 • item1: 4–x₁,
 • item3: 4–x₃,
 • item4: 2–x₄,
 • item5: 3–x₅,
with the following value for us:
 50(4–x₁) + 69(4–x₃) + 13(2–x₄) + 15(3–x₅) = 346.
A very natural and simple adjustment from Player 1’s offer [1,0,2,0,0] is to ask that we “keep” one unit more of one of the lower‐impact items – in this case, item4. Thus if we propose to give Player 1 the offer:
 [1, 0, 2, 1, 0]
then our allocation becomes:
 • item1: 4 – 1 = 3 units → 3×50 = 150,
 • item3: 4 – 2 = 2 units → 2×69 = 138,
 • item4: 2 – 1 = 1 unit → 1×13 = 13,
 • item5: 3 – 0 = 3 units → 3×15 = 45.
Total for us = 150 + 138 + 13 + 45 = 346.

Player 1’s allocation in this proposal would be:
 • item1: 1 unit,
 • item3: 2 units,
 • item4: 1 unit,
 • item5: all 3 units,
which (by our measure) sums to 50 + 138 + 13 = 201. This division exactly splits the total “pie” (547) into 346 for us and 201 for Player 1. (We note that although we use our own values to judge, this ensures we get well above our fallback while giving Player 1 an “indifferent” payoff relative to their likely outside offer.)

Since 346 > 201, we improve over our outside option. Given this reasoning, our best move in Round 1 is to counteroffer with [1, 0, 2, 1, 0].

Thus, my action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 0, 2, 1, 0]}

round_data.response:
I’ll explain my reasoning briefly. My guaranteed outcome (“outside offer”) is 265 in my own value‐units. Since I value the full bundle at 931, any deal giving me less than 265 isn’t attractive; so I want to ensure my “share” in any deal exceeds 265 when discounted. In round 1 there is no discount (γ^(r–1)=1), so my goal is a deal that’s clearly better than 265 while also giving Player 2 an incentive to reach agreement.

I can “design” a proposal by choosing how many units of each item to give to Player 2. (By definition our offer is what Player 2 gets; I get what remains.) A balanced starting point is to try a near–50:50 split (according to my own valuations). With my per–unit values:
 • item1: 18 (total 3)
 • item2: 64 (total 6)
 • item3: 100 (total 2)
 • item4: 91 (total 3)
 • item5: 5 (total 4)
I looked for a split so that the sum‐of–my–values for the items given to Player 2 is roughly 466 (with me keeping 465 out of 931). One way to achieve this is to assign to Player 2:
 • 2 units of item1: 2×18 = 36
 • 2 units of item2: 2×64 = 128
 • 1 unit of item3: 1×100 = 100
 • 2 units of item4: 2×91 = 182
 • all 4 units of item5: 4×5 = 20
The total (from my perspective) is 36+128+100+182+20 = 466 for Player 2. (That leaves me with 1 unit of item1, 4 units of item2, 1 unit of item3, 1 unit of item4, and 0 of item5; my value then is 18+256+100+91 = 465.) This division is clearly above my outside guarantee while it is “fair‐looking” from my view and might give Player 2 enough incentive to agree in round 1.

Thus, my action is to propose a counteroffer with the offer array [2, 2, 1, 2, 4].

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [2, 2, 1, 2, 4]}

I want to compare what I’d get if I accepted the current offer on the table versus what I can get with a well‐designed counteroffer. Right now the offer gives me
 • item 1: 0 units  (item value 100)
 • item 2: 1 unit  (item value 42)
 • item 3: 0 units  (item value 66)
 • item 4: 0 units  (item value 43)
 • item 5: 1 unit  (item value 2)
So my undiscounted value would be 0·100 + 1·42 + 0·66 + 0·43 + 1·2 = 44.
Because we’re in round 2 the discount factor is 0.9 so if I accepted I’d get 0.9×44 = 39.6.
That is very far below my outside option of 153.

To do better I want a deal that (after discounting) gives me at least as much as 153. In round 2 I therefore need an allocation to myself (that is, the complement of the offer I propose to player 2) whose undiscounted total value is at least 153/0.9, i.e. about 170. (I actually want much more than that so that I capture nearly all of the many high‐value items.)
Looking at my private values—
 item 1 (2 units): value 100 each,

 14x₁ + 10x₂ + 84x₃ + 23x₄ ≤ 60.

To maximize my outcome, I want to give away as little (in my terms) as possible while hopefully leaving Player 1 with enough to accept the deal. My “cheapest” item to concede is item 2 (10 per unit). I can afford to give at most 6 units in theory (6×10 = 60), but I only have 5 units total. So if I give away all 5 units of item 2, then my “cost” is 5×10 = 50, leaving me with a value of 688 − 50 = 638, which is above my outside offer.

Thus, my counteroffer is to give Player 1:  
 • 0 units of item 1  
 • 5 units of item 2  
 • 0 units of item 3  
 • 0 units of item 4  
 • 0 units of item 5  
In which case I keep:  
 • item 1: 3 units  
 • item 2: 0 units  
 • item 3: 6 units  
 • item 4: 4 units  
 • item 5: 0 units  
yielding a total value of 3×14 + 6×84 + 4×23 = 42 + 504 + 92 = 638.

Since 638 is above 628 and I am making only a minimal concession, my best action is to propose this counteroffer.

• Item 2: 3 – 0 = 3

• Item 4: 3 – 0 = 3  
• Item 5: 5 – 2 = 3

• Item 1: 1 × 47 = 47  
• Item 2: 3 × 2 = 6  
• Item 3: 4 × 53 = 212  
• Item 4: 3 × 41 = 123  
• Item 5: 3 × 93 = 279  

Sum = 47 + 6 + 212 + 123 + 279 = 667

My outside offer is 322, which is much lower than 600.3. Given that accepting now nets a high value, there is little gain and additional risk by trying to counteroffer (since any counteroffer would push the deal to round 3 with a further discount to 0.81).  

Thus, the best action is to ACCEPT the current offer.

round_data.response:
I first note that if we reach an agreement the present‐value payoff is not discounted (γ^(r–1)=1 in round 1) and my outside offer guarantees me 298 in value. Since my total value for all items is 1250, I must be sure to get a share worth at least 298. I also want to “push” as much value onto myself as possible while still offering Player 2 enough so that they prefer accepting rather than trying for a later (discounted) deal or their own outside offer.

A standard idea in these games is to try to claim the items that are most valuable to me while “offloading” those that I value less. My private per‐unit values are:
 • Item 1: 53  (3 units; total 159)
 • Item 2: 54  (5 units; total 270)
 • Item 3: 21  (4 units; total 84)
 • Item 4: 89  (6 units; total 534)
 • Item 5: 29  (7 units; total 203)
Total = 1250.

Notice that item 4 (worth 89 per unit) and items 1 and 2 are especially valuable to me. In contrast, items 3 (only 21 per unit) and 5 (29 per unit) are lower‐valued from my perspective—even though Player 2 might privately value them more.

I can “buy” my own guarantee (298) by keeping a relatively small share; however, to discourage Player 2 from trying to prolong the negotiation (and risk discounting their eventual gain by factor 0.9 in future rounds) it is good to offer them enough value from my perspective so that they’re likely to accept. A roughly “fair‐appearing” initial offer is one that gives Player 2 about 40–50% of the total value as I see it. (A 50–50 split in total value would be about 625 each. However, since my aim is to maximize my outcome, I want to offer just slightly less than half to Player 2 while still making their offer attractive relative to their outside option.)

One candidate allocation is as follows. I offer Player 2:
 • Item 1: 1 unit (leaving 2 for me; gives me 53)
 • Item 2: 2 units (leaving 3 for me; gives me 2×54=108 less value lost)
 • Item 3: All 4 units (since its low value for me)
 • Item 4: 1 unit (keeping most of the high‐value item)
 • Item 5: All 7 units (again, offload the lower priority item)

Let’s check what that means from my perspective:
 – My “offer” to Player 2 (the items they get) has value:
  Item 1: 1×53 = 53
  Item 2: 2×54 = 108
  Item 3: 4×21 = 84
  Item 4: 1×89 = 89
  Item 5: 7×29 = 203
  Total offered (value for me) = 53+108+84+89+203 = 537.
 – That leaves me with:
  Item 1: 2 units (2×53 = 106)
  Item 2: 3 units (3×54 = 162)
  Item 3: 0 units (0)
  Item 4: 5 units (5×89 = 445)
  Item 5: 0 units (0)
  Total kept = 106+162+445 = 713.

This division gives me 713 in value, which is well above my outside offer guarantee (298) while offering Player 2 an allocation worth 537 in my valuation. Although I do not know Player 2’s private values, this division uses my information advantage by keeping most of the items I value highly (item 4, and parts of items 1 and 2) and offering a “reasonable” share (537 vs. 713) that might be acceptable considering the discounting in later rounds.

Thus, my action in round 1 is to propose the division in which I give Player 2 the following: [1, 2, 4, 1, 7].

round_data.response:
Based on the calculations, here’s my reasoning:

My total value if I were to get everything is 
  Item1: 3×79 = 237  
  Item2: 5×23 = 115  
  Item3: 6×10 = 60  
  Item4: 2×100 = 200  
  Item5: 10×99 = 990  
  Total = 1602.

My private outside offer is worth 1582. That means if I try to split the items in a way that gives Player2 something, I can “concede” at most 20 points of my value (1602 – 1582 = 20). I would like to give concessions on items that are least valuable to me. In my case the lowest per‐unit value is on item 3 (only 10 per unit). Thus, if I were to offer even 1 unit of item 3, I lose 10 points (giving me 1592) which is only 10 points more than my fallback. Offering 2 units of item 3 (and nothing else) gives me exactly 1582 (i.e. 1602 – 2×10), and any further concession would drop my value below 1582.

From Player 2’s side the item(s) I would be giving up would likely be worth considerably more to them on expectation (since their values are drawn uniformly over a range up to 101), so it is highly unlikely that an offer where they receive only 1 or 2 units of our “low‐value” item (worth only 10 per unit to me) would beat their safely held outside offer. In effect, I have almost no meaningful surplus to share and any deal reached would leave me at most with my fallback value.

Given that any joint agreement —in this round with no discounting—would force me to concede some value that risks not enticing Player 2 while not giving me any gain above my outside offer, it is best to choose my guaranteed fallback.

Thus, my action is to WALK. 

{"action": "WALK"}

Adding up my share I get: 30 + 282 + 140 + 64 + 194 = 710, which is well above my fallback of 267. (Of course, Player 2’s exact evaluation depends on his private values, but by making an offer that fairly “splits” items I aim to give him enough incentive to accept even in round 1.)

  Item 3: 7 units → 7×50 = 350 
  Item 4: 6 units → 6×54 = 324

 Total = 324+360+350+324 = 1358, which is just above my outside offer of 1353.
5. This proposal gives me a small extra margin and sacrifices an item that is less valuable to me while potentially still being attractive to Player 2 (especially if Player 2 values item 5 highly).

Thus my action is:

I first check the current offer. Player 1’s offer would give me 0 of items 1–4 and 4 of item 5. With my private values (item 5 is 76 per unit) that totals 4×76 = 304. Since my outside option is 328, accepting that offer would be worse than simply walking away.

So I must make a counteroffer that—if accepted—must give me a deal whose value (without discount in round 1) is higher than my outside option. I also want to “split the pie” in a way that makes it plausible for Player 1 (who originally would have kept all of items 1–4 and none of item 5) to agree. One natural idea is to propose an equal-value division (from my perspective) of the overall set. The total value I would get if I received every unit is

  Item 1: 4×89 = 356  
  Item 2: 5×72 = 360  
  Item 3: 7×72 = 504  
  Item 4: 6×22 = 132  
  Item 5: 4×76 = 304  
  Total = 1656

An equal split of the total value means each “side” would have 1656/2 = 828 in my measure. (Note that I only know my own values and not Player 1’s; so fairness from my side seems a reasonable starting point.)  

One can find an allocation of quantities (X1, X2, X3, X4, X5) for me that gives exactly 828. For example, if I keep:
  Item 1: 2 units → 2×89 = 178  
  Item 2: 2 units → 2×72 = 144  
  Item 3: 4 units → 4×72 = 288  
  Item 4: 3 units → 3×22 = 66  
  Item 5: 2 units → 2×76 = 152  
Then my total value is 178+144+288+66+152 = 828.

Since I get whatever I do not offer, the counteroffer I present (i.e. what I give to Player 1) is just the leftover:
  Item 1: 4 – 2 = 2  
  Item 2: 5 – 2 = 3  
  Item 3: 7 – 4 = 3  
  Item 4: 6 – 3 = 3  
  Item 5: 4 – 2 = 2

This counteroffer gives me a present value of 828—well above my outside offer of 328—and is “fair” from my perspective. (It also gives Player 1 a complement that, if they value items similarly, might be attractive even though their private values could be different.)

In round 1 it is beneficial for me to move away from the unattractive current offer and propose this division. Therefore, my action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [2, 3, 3, 3, 2]}

round_data.response:
My reasoning:
• I know that if no deal is reached I get my outside offer of 540. So any deal must give me more than 540 (when discounted by γ^(r–1)=1 in round 1).
• My total value if I got everything would be 1314. I would like to keep most of the high‐value items. My per‐unit values are: item1=98, item2=73, item3=60, item4=64, item5=70.
• To improve the chances that Player 2 accepts, I want to give them a “fair” basket that (by my view) roughly splits the total surplus.
• I decide to keep both units of item1 and item2 (since they are most valuable for me) and also all of item5. That gives me:
  item1: 2×98 = 196,
  item2: 2×73 = 146,
  item5: 4×70 = 280,
  totaling 196+146+280 = 622.
• Of the remaining items, there are 3 units of item3 and 8 units of item4. I can afford to give away most of item4 (which by my value gives 64 per unit) and nearly all of item3 (60 per unit) to ensure Player 2’s basket is attractive enough relative to their outside option.
• I choose to keep 1 unit of item3 (value 60) and give away the remaining 2, and give away all 8 units of item4. Then my total value becomes:
  622 (from items 1,2,5) + 60 (kept from item3) = 682, which exceeds my outside offer of 540.
• In my view Player 2 would receive: 2 units of item3 (2×60 = 120) plus 8 units of item4 (8×64 = 512) for a total of 632. Although I don’t know their true values, this balanced (near–equal) split is a reasonable starting offer.
• Therefore, I propose to give Player 2 the following basket:
  [item1: 0, item2: 0, item3: 2, item4: 8, item5: 0].

Thus, my action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 0, 2, 8, 0]}

round_data.response:
I calculate that if I accept the current offer [1,1,1,4,2] then I’d receive:
 • Item 1: 1×64 = 64 
 • Item 2: 1×56 = 56 
 • Item 3: 1×37 = 37 
 • Item 4: 4×2 = 8 
 • Item 5: 2×81 = 162 
  Total = 64+56+37+8+162 = 327.
Because we are in round 2 the outcome is discounted by γ^(2–1)=0.9. Hence the present value is 0.9×327 = 294.3. Since my guaranteed outside offer is 339, accepting [1,1,1,4,2] would yield less than what I can get by walking away.

My goal is to end up with a deal that, even after the discount (and assuming we must eventually settle in round 3 if my counteroffer is accepted), gives me a raw (pre‐discount) value of at least about 418 (because 0.81×418 ≈ 338) so that my discounted value beats my outside alternative.

I value items 1 (64 per unit) and 5 (81 per unit) very highly, while item 4 is very low for me (only 2 per unit). In the current offer, I only get 1 unit of item 1 and 2 units of item 5 and so I leave significant value on the table. A natural idea is to try to “buy” those items by offering Player 1 more of the items I don’t value (especially item 4) in exchange. One strong possibility is to offer Player 1 all of item 4 (i.e. all 8 units) along with nothing of items 1, 2, and 5 so that I can get the full bundles of high‐value items. (For item 3 I must give enough away so the numbers add up.) 

Total quantities are: item 1:2, item 2:2, item 3:3, item 4:8, item 5:4.
If I offer Player 1 the bundle [0,0,2,8,0] then I keep the remainder:
 • Item 1: 2 – 0 = 2
 • Item 2: 2 – 0 = 2
 • Item 3: 3 – 2 = 1
 • Item 4: 8 – 8 = 0
 • Item 5: 4 – 0 = 4
My raw value becomes:
 2×64 + 2×56 + 1×37 + 0×2 + 4×81 = 128 + 112 + 37 + 0 + 324 = 601.
If the deal is reached in round 3 then it is discounted by γ^(3–1)=0.9²=0.81, giving me 0.81×601 ≈ 486.8—which is comfortably above my outside offer of 339.

Thus, I propose the counteroffer in which I offer Player 1 [0,0,2,8,0] (i.e. I “sell” them all of item 4 and 2 units of item 3) so that I can keep full control over the high‐value items. 

My response is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 0, 2, 8, 0]}

 657 – [18x1+31x2+56x3+62x4+5x5] ≥ 474 ⟹ 18x1+31x2+56x3+62x4+5x5 ≤ 183.

I want to design an offer that gives me a deal value a bit above 474 (to improve on my fallback) but also leaves Player 1 enough on their side to entice them to accept. round_data.response:
I want to propose an offer that guarantees my own payoff is high (well above my outside option of 290) while giving Player 2 a nonzero share so they’re more inclined to accept. My own per‐unit values are extremely high on item 1 (86 per unit) and more modest on the others (18, 16, 21, and 13). Because item 1 is so valuable to me I’d prefer to keep as many of those as possible—but if I give too little, Player 2 might dislike the deal if they in fact value item 1 highly. A common tactic is to concede a little on the highest‐value item so that the opponent sees that I’m not “taking everything,” while conceding more of the items that matter less to me (since those items might be relatively more valuable to them or at least “cheap” for me to part with).

A strategy I considered was:
 • For item 1 (4 available): Give 1 unit to Player 2 and keep 3. That gives me 3×86 = 258 (so I “lose” 86 compared to keeping all 4).
 • For item 2 (4 available): Give 2 to Player 2 (keep 2) → 2×18 = 36 for me.
 • For item 3 (6 available): Give 3 to Player 2 (keep 3) → 3×16 = 48.
 • For item 4 (7 available): Give 3 to Player 2 (keep 4) → 4×21 = 84.
 • For item 5 (5 available): Give 2 to Player 2 (keep 3) → 3×13 = 39.

My total value from the items I keep would be 258 + 36 + 48 + 84 + 39 = 465, which is considerably above my outside offer value of 290. This division also gives Player 2 a reasonable portion of the items (especially conceding one unit of item 1 avoids an overly greedy look).

Thus I propose offering Player 2 the following bundle:
 [1, 2, 3, 3, 2]

My response in the required JSON format is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 2, 3, 3, 2]}

round_data.response:
I want to propose an offer that “beats” my disagreement (outside) value. (Remember that by my own numbers I need to get at least 803 in value if the deal is reached in round 1 with no discount.) In this game I propose an offer in which I “give” player 2 a package (the offer “list” is what I give to player 2) and I “keep” the remainder. (My value for each item is my private (per‐unit) value multiplied by the number of units I end up with.) The totals available are

  item1: 4 units  
  item2: 6 units  
  item3: 3 units  
  item4: 8 units  
  item5: 4 units

and my per‐unit values are item1 = 76, item2 = 14, item3 = 26, item4 = 62, and item5 = 76. (My total “full‐package” value is 1266.) I also have an outside option that guarantees me 803 value.

A “good” offer must (a) give me a share (i.e. the items I keep) that is worth at least 803 by my own numbers and (b) be “attractive” enough that player 2 (whose private values we do not know but who on average “sees” the items as having roughly a midpoint value) instead of walking – that is, the package I offer them should be competitive with what they expect by “disagreement.”

For instance, note that – from my perspective – I value items 1 and 5 very highly (76 per unit) and item4 almost as high (62 per unit), while items 2 (14 per unit) and 3 (26 per unit) are “cheaper” for me. A common tactic is to “concede” (offer entirely) the units of the “low‐value” items so that player 2 gets many units of something that might be more valuable to them. (When the “outside option” is drawn from the total value, player 2’s contract offer will likely come out higher than what I “feel” for those low–value items.) In order not to “hurt” my own outcome, the amount I give away in terms of my own valuations must be no more than 1266 – 803 = 463 in “concession value.”

One possibility is as follows. Suppose I “give” player 2 all of items 2 and 3. That yields by my numbers 
  item2: 6 × 14 = 84  
  item3: 3 × 26 = 78  
  concession = 84 + 78 = 162.
That leaves 463 – 162 = 301 “value units” that I can concede from items where my per–unit value is higher. But I do not want to give away too many of the highest‐value items (items 1 and 5) because they are 76 per unit; however, it is plausible that player 2 expects to value those items highly too so giving them a few units helps “sell” the proposal.
One reasonable initial offer is then to “give” player 2:
  • 1 unit of item 1  (1 × 76 = 76)  
  • all 6 units of item 2  (84)  
  • all 3 units of item 3  (78)  
  • 1 unit of item 4  (62)  
  • 2 units of item 5  (2 × 76 = 152)
The total “conceded” value from my perspective is 76 + 84 + 78 + 62 + 152 = 452. Then I “keep” (total minus what I give to player 2) the following:
  • item 1: 4 – 1 = 3 units → 3 × 76 = 228  
  • item 2: 6 – 6 = 0 units → 0  
  • item 3: 3 – 3 = 0 units → 0  
  • item 4: 8 – 1 = 7 units → 7 × 62 = 434  
  • item 5: 4 – 2 = 2 units → 2 × 76 = 152  
So my retained value = 228 + 0 + 0 + 434 + 152 = 814, which is above my outside offer guarantee of 803.

This offer leaves player 2 with a “high‐quantity” bundle of items 2 and 3 (which I value low but which—given player 2’s unknown values—could be quite attractive) along with a modest quantity (1 or 2 units) of the high–value items 1, 4, and 5. Overall, by my valuation the package I keep is 814 (a slight improvement over my disagreement payoff) while player 2 gets a bundle that by expected standards (given uniform draws on values from 1 to 101) should be competitive with their outside option.

Therefore my initial counteroffer is to give player 2 the following division: [1, 6, 3, 1, 2].

Thus my JSON action is:

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [1, 6, 3, 1, 2]}

• Item 4: 52 (3 units available) Total possible value = 3×52 = 156  
• Item 5: 54 (4 units available) Total possible value = 4×54 = 216  
     _______________________________  
     Total = 660  

My guarantee if I “WALK” is an outside offer of value 529. Thus, if I propose a division (by offering Player 2 some items) I want my own “kept” bundle to be worth at least 529 (and ideally only slightly above so that I maximize my share while giving just enough to be attractive for Player 2).

I can control the division by offering a list [n1, n2, n3, n4, n5] where each n is the units given to Player 2 of that item. My own share per item is (total available – offered units). My total value will then be:

  Value = 7×(2 – n1) + 79×(2 – n2) + 58×(2 – n3) + 52×(3 – n4) + 54×(4 – n5).

A good strategic plan is to “concede” those items I value less and keep items I value highly so that my own share’s total value is just above 529. Among the items, Item 1 is very low (7/unit) so I want to give it away completely. Also, I can “sacrifice” the entire allotment of a moderately valued item such as Item 3 (58/unit) in order to provide something attractive to Player 2. In contrast, I want to keep all of Item 2 (79/unit), Item 4 (52/unit) and Item 5 (54/unit).

 • Offer none of Item 2: n2 = 0  
 • Offer all of Item 3: n3 = 2  
 • Offer none of Item 4: n4 = 0  
 • Offer none of Item 5: n5 = 0

Then my retained units become:

 • Item 2: 2 units  
 • Item 3: 0 units  
 • Item 4: 3 units  
 • Item 5: 4 units

Computing my total value:

 • Item 2: 2×79 = 158  
 • Item 3: 0×58 = 0  
 • Item 4: 3×52 = 156  
 • Item 5: 4×54 = 216  
  Total = 158 + 156 + 216 = 530

This gives me a total value of 530 – just 1 point above my outside offer of 529. (Getting even a slight improvement is worthwhile.) Also, by giving all units of Item 1 (which I value very little) and all units of Item 3, I provide Player 2 a solid bundle that might be worthwhile relative to their outside option. (Their private values are unknown, but this may be attractive.) 

Thus, I propose my initial offer as: give Player 2: [2, 0, 2, 0, 0]. This is a valid counteroffer meeting my own reservation (530 > 529) while keeping as many high–value (for me) items.

So my action is:

I'll first evaluate the current offer. If I accept the current offer [2, 2, 1, 3, 2] as given to me by Player 1, then my bundle would be:

• Item 1: 2 units → 2 × 20 = 40  
• Item 2: 2 units → 2 × 35 = 70  
• Item 3: 1 unit  → 1 × 62 = 62  
• Item 4: 3 units → 3 × 13 = 39  
• Item 5: 2 units → 2 × 60 = 120  

Total value if I accept = 40 + 70 + 62 + 39 + 120 = 331

However, my private outside offer is 622, so 331 is much lower than what I can guarantee by walking. Therefore, I must counter.

I can propose a division where I offer Player 1 a small amount – just enough that, if a deal is reached, I still get a bundle valued above 622. Since the total available items are:
  
• Item 1: 5 units  
• Item 2: 4 units  
• Item 3: 2 units  
• Item 4: 6 units  
• Item 5: 5 units  
  
My total value if I got everything would be:
  
5×20 + 4×35 + 2×62 + 6×13 + 5×60 = 100 + 140 + 124 + 78 + 300 = 742.
  
I need to keep a retained value (for the items I keep, i.e. total minus what I offer Player 1) of at least 622. That means I can “concede” at most 742 − 622 = 120 in my own value.

I want to give as little as possible to improve the chance of agreement while still making Player 1 an attractive counteroffer. One natural idea is to give a unit of an item that has a relatively high value for Player 1 (and even though it costs me something, I can still remain above my threshold). For me, a single unit of item 5 is worth 60. If I offer Player 1 1 unit of item 5, then my retained bundle is: 

• Item 1: 5  
• Item 2: 4  
• Item 3: 2  
• Item 4: 6  
• Item 5: 5 − 1 = 4  

My retained value becomes:
  
• Item 1: 5×20 = 100  
• Item 2: 4×35 = 140  
• Item 3: 2×62 = 124  
• Item 4: 6×13 = 78  
• Item 5: 4×60 = 240  

Total = 100 + 140 + 124 + 78 + 240 = 682

This overall value (682) is above my outside offer of 622. Thus, my counteroffer yields me a superior outcome if a deal is reached, while giving Player 1 a potential incentive (they get 1 unit of item 5).

Thus, I propose the following counteroffer, meaning I am offering Player 1 exactly 1 unit of item 5 (and nothing from the other items):

{"action": "COUNTEROFFER", "offer": [0, 0, 0, 0, 1]}

round_data.response:
After analyzing the situation, here is my reasoning:

• In the current offer from Player 1 (giving me [0, 0, 0, 2, 2]) I would receive 2 units of item 4 and 2 units of item 5. With my private per‐unit values (item 4 = 13 and item 5 = 60), that gives me a total raw value of 2×13 + 2×60 = 26 + 120 = 146. With a discount factor of 0.9 in round 2 the present value is 0.9×146 = 131.4, which is far below my guaranteed outside offer of 622.

• If I try a counteroffer, I must make sure that my negotiated deal (after discounting) has a raw value of at least 622/0.9 ≈ 691 in order to beat my outside option. Since my total maximum raw value if I got everything is 742, I could in theory afford to give up at most 742 – 691 ≈ 51 “points” of value. However, because of my own value weights the “cost” for me per unit is: 20 for item1, 35 for item2, 62 for item3, 13 for item4, and 60 for item5. This means that even giving up a single unit of items 3 or 5 (which are very valuable to me) already costs more than 51. Thus any counteroffer intended to keep my deal better than 622 must give up only items where the cost is low—in this case maybe items 1, 2 or especially 4. 

• To entice Player 1 to accept my counteroffer they should receive a bundle that is at least as attractive as what they have already proposed. In the current offer the allocation (from my perspective) is that Player 1 would get all of item 1 (5 units), item 2 (4), item 3 (2), plus 6 – 2 = 4 units of item 4 and 5 – 2 = 3 units of item 5. It would be extremely difficult for me to give up nearly that many items (or even parts of the ones I value modestly) without sacrificing so much of my own raw value that my share would drop below the threshold needed (about 691 raw value, i.e. 0.9×raw ≥622).

• Given that any counteroffer which gives Player 1 a sufficiently attractive share would force me to give up items “worth” in excess of 51 points from my side—thus lowering my own total below the breakeven value—and that the current offer gives me a very poor outcome (131.4 vs. 622), my best option is to WALK away and secure my outside offer of 622.

Thus, my action is:

{"action": "WALK"}
